name: CLI Basics
description: The Linux command line is your gateway to cloud infrastructure. Work through Linux Basics for Hackers chapter by chapter to prepare for the CTF challenges.

learning_steps.title: Linux Basics for Hackers, 2nd Edition
learning_steps.description: Purchase or borrow Linux Basics for Hackers by OccupyTheWeb. We'll work through chapters 1-9, which cover everything you need for the CTF challenges.

learning_steps.text: Chapter 1: Getting Started with the Basics
learning_steps.title: Getting Started with the Basics
learning_steps.description: Learn essential navigation commands: pwd, cd, ls, whoami, and getting help with man pages. Understand the Linux filesystem hierarchy.

learning_steps.title: Text Manipulation
learning_steps.description: Learn to view and manipulate text files using cat, head, tail, grep, and sed. Master pipes and redirects for chaining commands.

learning_steps.title: Analyzing and Managing Networks
learning_steps.description: Learn network analysis commands: ifconfig/ip, iwconfig, dig, and DNS configuration. Essential for cloud engineering.

learning_steps.title: Adding and Removing Software
learning_steps.description: Learn package management with apt: searching, installing, updating, and removing software.

learning_steps.text: Chapter 5: Controlling File and Directory Permissions
learning_steps.title: Controlling File and Directory Permissions
learning_steps.description: Master Linux permissions: understanding rwx, chmod, chown, and special permissions. Critical for security.

learning_steps.title: Process Management
learning_steps.description: Learn to view and manage processes with ps, top, kill, and nice. Essential for troubleshooting.

learning_steps.title: Managing User Environment Variables
learning_steps.description: Understand environment variables like PATH, HOME, and how to configure them in .bashrc.

learning_steps.title: Bash Scripting
learning_steps.description: Introduction to bash scripting: variables, conditionals, loops. Free sample chapter available!

learning_steps.title: Compressing and Archiving
learning_steps.description: Learn to work with compressed files using tar, gzip, bzip2. Used constantly for logs and backups.

learning_steps.title: OverTheWire Bandit
learning_steps.description: A free wargame that reinforces Linux commands through progressively harder challenges. Great extra practice before the CTF.

questions.prompt: Walk me through the Linux file permission system and how read, write, and execute differ for files versus directories.
scenario_seeds: A new team member accidentally set a deployment script to 777 permissions and your security team flagged it
Your web application can't read its config file after a server migration and you need to diagnose the permission issue
You're setting up a shared project directory where developers need to create files but shouldn't modify each other's work
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain the rwx triplet for owner/group/others AND differentiate how permissions behave on files vs directories (read=list contents, execute=enter directory) AND demonstrate understanding of chmod usage.

questions.prompt: How would you explain pipes and redirects in Linux to someone learning the command line? Give an example of each.
scenario_seeds: You need to find all error messages in a 2GB log file and save them to a separate file for the on-call engineer
Your CI/CD pipeline needs to process command output through multiple filters before storing results
A junior developer asks why their script output disappeared when they used > instead of >> on an important file
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain pipes as connecting stdout of one command to stdin of another AND explain redirects for sending output to files AND provide working examples of both | and > or >> operators.

test_knowledge_prompts: Can you quiz me on Linux file permissions?
Can you ask me about pipes and redirects?

learning_objectives.text: Get Linux Basics for Hackers book
